thread.title: Former Newcastle Airport boss David Laws takes top job at Northern rival

author: Graeme Whitfield
title: Former Newcastle Airport boss David Laws takes top job at Northern rival
text:
Former Newcastle Airport boss David Laws takes top job at Northern rival Mr Laws has been appointed as chief executive of Leeds Bradford Airport Share David Laws, chief executive at Leeds Bradford Airport (Photo: publicity handout from Leeds Bradford Airport) Share Get business updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! The former head of Newcastle Airport has been appointed to take charge of a rival site in the North. 
Leeds Bradford Airport has appointed David Laws as its new chief executive after the retirement of John Parkin, another former boss at Newcastle. 
Mr Laws held the top job at Newcastle for 10 years and had worked there since 1979 but stepped down from his role last year. His time in charge at Newcastle saw expansion in passenger numbers and the addition of a number of key flight destinations, including Dubai and New York, though the American link has since been cancelled. 
Mr Laws, who also oversaw substantial re-development of the airport, had been working in a part-time advisory role for Newcastle’s co-owners AMP Capital after leaving the airport. 
Now he is promising similar developments at Newcastle’s nearest large rival airport in the North. 
He said: “My passion is for airport development and ensuring that the customer journey is a truly great experience. 
“I am excited about joining Leeds Bradford Airport to further improve, expand and develop the business and look forward to working with the team at Leeds Bradford Airport and all those involved from the airlines, stakeholders and partners to develop the next phase of the airport’s growth.” Read More Avoiding hard Brexit is keen concern for North East businesses, Journal survey shows 
Despite serving a larger population, Leeds Bradford Airport is smaller than Newcastle, serving 3.6m passengers a year to Newcastle’s 4.8m. The Yorkshire Airport had 44,000 flights last year compared to Newcastle’s 56,000. 
Earlier this year Newcastle Airport confirmed that Nick Jones, who had been interim chief executive since Mr Laws’ departure, would take the top job on a permanent basis. He had been at the airport since 2015, having joined as chief financial officer. 
Mr Jones took the top job at a time when the airport is experiencing its strongest growth in almost a decade, with passenger numbers growing by 6% in 2016 and a number of new routes being announced. Read More
